# History of Kendama 

## Origins

- Kendama traces its roots back to 16th–19th century France, where a similar toy called "Bilboquet" was popular among the aristocracy.
- Early versions were made from animal bones, later evolving into cup-and-ball structures, eventually adding a spike and a hole in the ball.


## Arrival in Japan

- Kendama was introduced to Japan through Nagasaki during the Edo period (18th century), likely by returning students or traders.
- It was initially known by various names such as "Kendama," "Kendama-fist," and "Shichiyoku-ken."
- Besides being a toy, it was sometimes used for fortune-telling or as a drinking game.
<iframe width="560" height="500" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-9A-sy5k7-Q?si=fdYjpAtEadpAl1SD" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

## Modern Kendama

- In the Taisho era (around 1919), Hamaji Egusa from Hiroshima improved the design, adding three cups and a spike, and called it "Nichigetsu Ball" (日月球), symbolizing the sun and moon.
- In 1919, Egusa patented this design, leading to mass production and nationwide popularity in Japan.


## Standardization and Competitive Play

- In 1975, the Japan Kendama Association was established, standardizing the name "Kendama," setting official specifications, and defining basic techniques.
- The association also introduced a ranking system and the "10 Basic Tricks," promoting Kendama as both a sport and an educational tool.


## Kendama in Taiwan

- In 2009, the "Chinese Kendama Association" was founded in Taiwan to promote Kendama culture and organize events.


## Global Development

- Today, Kendama is a worldwide skill toy and sport, with a vibrant community and competitions in Japan, Europe, the US, and beyond.


### References

- Wikipedia: [Kendama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendama)
- Kendama USA: [History of Kendama](https://www.kendamausa.com/history)
- Hong Kong Kendama Association: [Origin of Kendama](https://www.hkka.org.hk/)
- Fun! Japan: [Kendama History](https://www.fun-japan.jp/en/articles/10947)
- Tsunagu Japan: [Kendama Introduction](https://www.tsunagujapan.com/kendama-japanese-toy/)

# 劍玉的歷史

## 起源

- 劍玉（けん玉，Kendama）最早可追溯至16至19世紀的法國，當時稱為「Bilboquet」，是一種將球體與木棒結合的遊戲，深受法國貴族喜愛[1][2][3]。
- 初期的劍玉以獸骨製成，後來逐漸演變成杯狀，最終發展出尖端與底部皿的結構，球體也增加了洞口[1][3][4]。

## 傳入日本

- 約在江戶時代（18世紀），劍玉由留學生帶入日本長崎[1][3][5]。
- 傳入初期，名稱多變，如「拳玉」、「七玉拳」等[1][5]。
- 劍玉不僅作為玩具，也曾用於占卜或飲酒遊戲[6]。

## 現代劍玉的誕生

- 大正時代（約1919年），日本廣島的江草濱次改良了劍玉結構，設計出三個皿與一個尖端，並命名為「日月球」，象徵太陽與月亮的結合[3][5][6]。
- 1919年，「日月球」獲得專利，並開始量產，劍玉逐漸成為日本全國流行的玩具[1][6]。

## 規則與競技化

- 1975年，日本劍玉協會成立，統一名稱為「けん玉」（Kendama），並制定了劍玉的標準規格與基本技巧，推動劍玉邁向競技與教育領域[1][2][3]。
- 劍玉的級位、段位制度和基本十招也在此時確立[2][3]。
<iframe width="560" height="500" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TfR_8L8eWB8?si=NPbnzJjjPud6IfIx" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

## 劍玉在台灣

- 2009年，台灣成立了全國性的「中華劍球劍玉運動協會」，推廣劍玉文化[1]。

## 劍玉的現代發展

- 劍玉已成為全球知名的技巧運動與娛樂玩具，不僅在日本，歐美等地也有眾多玩家與比賽[2][3][5]。

title: 雜耍球
content:
# The History of Juggling Balls

## Ancient Origins

- **The earliest records of juggling** appear in Ancient Egypt, around 1994–1781 BCE. Tomb paintings in Beni Hasan depict female dancers and acrobats tossing balls, showing that the history of juggling balls spans over 4,000 years[1][2][3].
- **Ancient China** also documents juggling. For example, during the Western Han Dynasty, the warrior Xiong Yiliao was said to have juggled nine balls on the battlefield, intimidating enemy troops[4].
- **Ancient Greece, Rome, India, and Ireland** also have early records of juggling. For instance, the Roman juggler Tagatus Ursus was said to perform with glass balls in the 1st century CE[5][6].

## Middle Ages and Renaissance

- With the decline of the Roman Empire, juggling in Europe was often seen as a lowly or even magical act, relegated to marketplaces, streets, and taverns[4].
- By the late Middle Ages, juggling gradually regained its reputation, becoming part of court entertainment and integrating with music, poetry, and storytelling[2].

## Modern Development of Juggling Balls

### 18th–19th Centuries

- **1768:** Philip Astley founded the first modern circus in England, making juggling an important part of circus performances[1][2].
- **19th century:** Asian juggling troupes (from India and Japan) introduced new techniques to Europe, promoting the diverse development of juggling arts[7].

### Evolution of Materials and Props

- Early juggling balls were made from stone, wood, leather, metal, clay, and paper. String balls were used in China and Japan, while leather balls were common in Europe[5][8].
- **Late 19th century:** With the invention of rubber and plastic, juggling balls began to be mass-produced, including bounce balls and inflatable balls, making juggling techniques more diverse[5][4].
- **Modern juggling balls** are mostly made from plastic, rubber, or synthetic materials and come in various sizes and weights to suit different performance needs[9].

### 20th Century to Present

- **Early 20th century:** Juggling became part of vaudeville performances, leading to the rise of many professional jugglers and innovative techniques[1][2].
- **1947:** The International Jugglers’ Association was founded, promoting the global development of juggling[1].
- Today, juggling balls are not only tools for professional performers but also a popular recreational activity among enthusiasts worldwide[2][4].

## Cultural Diversity

- **Indigenous peoples of the Americas**, **Pacific Islanders**, and the **Aztec civilization** also have traditional forms of juggling balls, sometimes incorporating juggling into religious rituals[2][10].
- **Japan’s Otedama** is a beanbag juggling game that originated from China and was introduced to Japan around 710 CE[8].

The history of juggling balls spans thousands of years, from ancient Egyptian murals to modern circuses and street performances. Juggling balls not only showcase human dexterity and creativity but also reflect the exchange and fusion of different eras and cultures[5][1][2].

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_juggling  
[2] https://www.topendsports.com/sport/juggling/history.htm  
[3] http://www.juggling.org/papers/history-4/  
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juggling  
[5] https://www.jonglerieetjonglages.fr/en/objets.html  
[6] https://sites.google.com/bc.edu/arthur-lewbel/history-of-juggling  
[7] https://cirque-cnac.bnf.fr/en/juggling/juggling/origins

[9] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juggling_ball  
[10] https://www.oddballs.co.uk/blogs/news/the-history-of-juggling
contentZh:
# 雜耍球的歷史

## 古代起源

- **最早的雜耍記錄**出現在古埃及，約公元前1994年至1781年。埃及Beni Hasan墓壁畫描繪了女性舞者和雜技演員拋接球的場景，這些圖像顯示雜耍球的歷史已有超過4000年[1][2][3]。
- **中國古代**也有雜耍的記載，例如西漢時期的勇士熊宜僚據說在戰場上拋接九顆球，嚇退敵軍[4]。
- **希臘、羅馬、印度和愛爾蘭**等地也有古老的雜耍記錄。例如，羅馬雜耍家Tagatus Ursus據說在公元1世紀使用玻璃球表演[5][6]。

## 中世紀與文藝復興

- 隨著羅馬帝國的衰落，雜耍在歐洲一度被視為低賤甚至與巫術相關的表演，只能在市集、街頭和酒館中進行[4]。
- 到了中世紀晚期，雜耍逐漸恢復名聲，成為宮廷娛樂的一部分，並與音樂、詩歌和故事講述結合[2]。

## 現代雜耍球的發展

### 18-19世紀

- **1768年**，英國的Philip Astley創辦了第一個現代馬戲團，雜耍成為馬戲團表演的重要部分[1][2]。
- **19世紀**，亞洲的雜耍團體（如印度、日本）將新技術帶入歐洲，推動了雜耍藝術的多元發展[7]。

### 材料與道具的演進

- 早期的雜耍球材料包括石頭、木頭、皮革、金屬、黏土和紙張。中國和日本曾使用線球，歐洲則常用皮革球[5][8]。
- **19世紀末**，隨著橡膠和塑膠的發明，雜耍球開始大量生產，並出現了彈跳球與充氣球，讓雜耍技巧更加多元[5][4]。
- **現代**雜耍球多以塑膠、橡膠或合成材料製成，並有各種尺寸與重量，適合不同表演需求[9]。

### 20世紀至今

- **20世紀初**，雜耍與音樂廳（Vaudeville）表演結合，催生了許多專業雜耍家與創新技巧[1][2]。
- **1947年**，國際雜耍家協會成立，推動全球雜耍運動的發展[1]。
- 今日，雜耍球不僅是專業表演者的道具，也是全球各地愛好者的熱門休閒活動[2][4]。

## 文化多樣性

- **美洲原住民**、**太平洋島嶼**、**阿茲特克文明**等地區也有雜耍球的傳統，部分文化甚至將雜耍結合宗教儀式[2][10]。
- **日本的御手玉（Otedama）**是源自中國的豆袋雜耍遊戲，約於公元710年傳入日本[8]。

雜耍球的歷史橫跨數千年，從古埃及壁畫到現代馬戲團與街頭藝術，雜耍球不僅展現人類的靈巧與創意，也反映了不同時代與文化的交流與融合[5][1][2]。

# The History of Juggling Balls

## Ancient Origins
<iframe width="560" height="505" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/LzgMUXZ91y0?si=azm-6G4sEJnHxDma" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

- **The earliest records of juggling** appear in Ancient Egypt, around 1994–1781 BCE. Tomb paintings in Beni Hasan depict female dancers and acrobats tossing balls, showing that the history of juggling balls spans over 4,000 years[1][2][3].
- **Ancient China** also documents juggling. For example, during the Western Han Dynasty, the warrior Xiong Yiliao was said to have juggled nine balls on the battlefield, intimidating enemy troops[4].
- **Ancient Greece, Rome, India, and Ireland** also have early records of juggling. For instance, the Roman juggler Tagatus Ursus was said to perform with glass balls in the 1st century CE[5][6].

## Middle Ages and Renaissance

- With the decline of the Roman Empire, juggling in Europe was often seen as a lowly or even magical act, relegated to marketplaces, streets, and taverns[4].
- By the late Middle Ages, juggling gradually regained its reputation, becoming part of court entertainment and integrating with music, poetry, and storytelling[2].

## Modern Development of Juggling Balls

### 18th–19th Centuries

- **1768:** Philip Astley founded the first modern circus in England, making juggling an important part of circus performances[1][2].
- **19th century:** Asian juggling troupes (from India and Japan) introduced new techniques to Europe, promoting the diverse development of juggling arts[7].

### Evolution of Materials and Props

- Early juggling balls were made from stone, wood, leather, metal, clay, and paper. String balls were used in China and Japan, while leather balls were common in Europe[5][8].
- **Late 19th century:** With the invention of rubber and plastic, juggling balls began to be mass-produced, including bounce balls and inflatable balls, making juggling techniques more diverse[5][4].
- **Modern juggling balls** are mostly made from plastic, rubber, or synthetic materials and come in various sizes and weights to suit different performance needs[9].

### 20th Century to Present

- **Early 20th century:** Juggling became part of vaudeville performances, leading to the rise of many professional jugglers and innovative techniques[1][2].
- **1947:** The International Jugglers’ Association was founded, promoting the global development of juggling[1].
- Today, juggling balls are not only tools for professional performers but also a popular recreational activity among enthusiasts worldwide[2][4].

## Cultural Diversity

- **Indigenous peoples of the Americas**, **Pacific Islanders**, and the **Aztec civilization** also have traditional forms of juggling balls, sometimes incorporating juggling into religious rituals[2][10].
- **Japan’s Otedama** is a beanbag juggling game that originated from China and was introduced to Japan around 710 CE[8].

The history of juggling balls spans thousands of years, from ancient Egyptian murals to modern circuses and street performances. Juggling balls not only showcase human dexterity and creativity but also reflect the exchange and fusion of different eras and cultures[5][1][2].

# 雜耍球的歷史

## 古代起源

<iframe width="560" height="505" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/WQCjlbw72no?si=8GkzzCslXsvyozQS" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>
- **最早的雜耍記錄**出現在古埃及，約公元前1994年至1781年。埃及Beni Hasan墓壁畫描繪了女性舞者和雜技演員拋接球的場景，這些圖像顯示雜耍球的歷史已有超過4000年[1][2][3]。
- **中國古代**也有雜耍的記載，例如西漢時期的勇士熊宜僚據說在戰場上拋接九顆球，嚇退敵軍[4]。
- **希臘、羅馬、印度和愛爾蘭**等地也有古老的雜耍記錄。例如，羅馬雜耍家Tagatus Ursus據說在公元1世紀使用玻璃球表演[5][6]。

## 中世紀與文藝復興

- 隨著羅馬帝國的衰落，雜耍在歐洲一度被視為低賤甚至與巫術相關的表演，只能在市集、街頭和酒館中進行[4]。
- 到了中世紀晚期，雜耍逐漸恢復名聲，成為宮廷娛樂的一部分，並與音樂、詩歌和故事講述結合[2]。

## 現代雜耍球的發展

### 18-19世紀

- **1768年**，英國的Philip Astley創辦了第一個現代馬戲團，雜耍成為馬戲團表演的重要部分[1][2]。
- **19世紀**，亞洲的雜耍團體（如印度、日本）將新技術帶入歐洲，推動了雜耍藝術的多元發展[7]。

### 材料與道具的演進

- 早期的雜耍球材料包括石頭、木頭、皮革、金屬、黏土和紙張。中國和日本曾使用線球，歐洲則常用皮革球[5][8]。
- **19世紀末**，隨著橡膠和塑膠的發明，雜耍球開始大量生產，並出現了彈跳球與充氣球，讓雜耍技巧更加多元[5][4]。
- **現代**雜耍球多以塑膠、橡膠或合成材料製成，並有各種尺寸與重量，適合不同表演需求[9]。

### 20世紀至今

- **20世紀初**，雜耍與音樂廳（Vaudeville）表演結合，催生了許多專業雜耍家與創新技巧[1][2]。
- **1947年**，國際雜耍家協會成立，推動全球雜耍運動的發展[1]。
- 今日，雜耍球不僅是專業表演者的道具，也是全球各地愛好者的熱門休閒活動[2][4]。

## 文化多樣性

- **美洲原住民**、**太平洋島嶼**、**阿茲特克文明**等地區也有雜耍球的傳統，部分文化甚至將雜耍結合宗教儀式[2][10]。
- **日本的御手玉（Otedama）**是源自中國的豆袋雜耍遊戲，約於公元710年傳入日本[8]。

雜耍球的歷史橫跨數千年，從古埃及壁畫到現代馬戲團與街頭藝術，雜耍球不僅展現人類的靈巧與創意，也反映了不同時代與文化的交流與融合[5][1][2]。

# History of Kendama 

## Origins

- Kendama traces its roots back to 16th–19th century France, where a similar toy called "Bilboquet" was popular among the aristocracy.
- Early versions were made from animal bones, later evolving into cup-and-ball structures, eventually adding a spike and a hole in the ball.


## Arrival in Japan

- Kendama was introduced to Japan through Nagasaki during the Edo period (18th century), likely by returning students or traders.
- It was initially known by various names such as "Kendama," "Kendama-fist," and "Shichiyoku-ken."
- Besides being a toy, it was sometimes used for fortune-telling or as a drinking game.
<iframe width="560" height="500" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/-9A-sy5k7-Q?si=fdYjpAtEadpAl1SD" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

## Modern Kendama

- In the Taisho era (around 1919), Hamaji Egusa from Hiroshima improved the design, adding three cups and a spike, and called it "Nichigetsu Ball" (日月球), symbolizing the sun and moon.
- In 1919, Egusa patented this design, leading to mass production and nationwide popularity in Japan.


## Standardization and Competitive Play

- In 1975, the Japan Kendama Association was established, standardizing the name "Kendama," setting official specifications, and defining basic techniques.
- The association also introduced a ranking system and the "10 Basic Tricks," promoting Kendama as both a sport and an educational tool.


## Kendama in Taiwan

- In 2009, the "Chinese Kendama Association" was founded in Taiwan to promote Kendama culture and organize events.


## Global Development

- Today, Kendama is a worldwide skill toy and sport, with a vibrant community and competitions in Japan, Europe, the US, and beyond.


### References

- Wikipedia: [Kendama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendama)
- Kendama USA: [History of Kendama](https://www.kendamausa.com/history)
- Hong Kong Kendama Association: [Origin of Kendama](https://www.hkka.org.hk/)
- Fun! Japan: [Kendama History](https://www.fun-japan.jp/en/articles/10947)
- Tsunagu Japan: [Kendama Introduction](https://www.tsunagujapan.com/kendama-japanese-toy/)

# 劍玉的歷史

## 起源

- 劍玉（けん玉，Kendama）最早可追溯至16至19世紀的法國，當時稱為「Bilboquet」，是一種將球體與木棒結合的遊戲，深受法國貴族喜愛[1][2][3]。
- 初期的劍玉以獸骨製成，後來逐漸演變成杯狀，最終發展出尖端與底部皿的結構，球體也增加了洞口[1][3][4]。

## 傳入日本

- 約在江戶時代（18世紀），劍玉由留學生帶入日本長崎[1][3][5]。
- 傳入初期，名稱多變，如「拳玉」、「七玉拳」等[1][5]。
- 劍玉不僅作為玩具，也曾用於占卜或飲酒遊戲[6]。

## 現代劍玉的誕生

- 大正時代（約1919年），日本廣島的江草濱次改良了劍玉結構，設計出三個皿與一個尖端，並命名為「日月球」，象徵太陽與月亮的結合[3][5][6]。
- 1919年，「日月球」獲得專利，並開始量產，劍玉逐漸成為日本全國流行的玩具[1][6]。

## 規則與競技化

- 1975年，日本劍玉協會成立，統一名稱為「けん玉」（Kendama），並制定了劍玉的標準規格與基本技巧，推動劍玉邁向競技與教育領域[1][2][3]。
- 劍玉的級位、段位制度和基本十招也在此時確立[2][3]。
<iframe width="560" height="500" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TfR_8L8eWB8?si=NPbnzJjjPud6IfIx" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

## 劍玉在台灣

- 2009年，台灣成立了全國性的「中華劍球劍玉運動協會」，推廣劍玉文化[1]。

## 劍玉的現代發展

- 劍玉已成為全球知名的技巧運動與娛樂玩具，不僅在日本，歐美等地也有眾多玩家與比賽[2][3][5]。

- It was initially known by various names such as "Kendama," "Kendama-fist," and "Shichiyoku-ken."
- Besides being a toy, it was sometimes used for fortune-telling or as a drinking game.

## Modern Kendama

- In the Taisho era (around 1919), Hamaji Egusa from Hiroshima improved the design, adding three cups and a spike, and called it "Nichigetsu Ball" (日月球), symbolizing the sun and moon.
- In 1919, Egusa patented this design, leading to mass production and nationwide popularity in Japan.

## Standardization and Competitive Play

- In 1975, the Japan Kendama Association was established, standardizing the name "Kendama," setting official specifications, and defining basic techniques.
- The association also introduced a ranking system and the "10 Basic Tricks," promoting Kendama as both a sport and an educational tool.

## Kendama in Taiwan

- In 2009, the "Chinese Kendama Association" was founded in Taiwan to promote Kendama culture and organize events.

## Global Development

- Today, Kendama is a worldwide skill toy and sport, with a vibrant community and competitions in Japan, Europe, the US, and beyond.

- Kendama USA: [History of Kendama](https://www.kendamausa.com/history)
- Hong Kong Kendama Association: [Origin of Kendama](https://www.hkka.org.hk/)

- Tsunagu Japan: [Kendama Introduction](https://www.tsunagujapan.com/kendama-japanese-toy/)

# 劍玉的歷史

## 起源

- 劍玉（けん玉，Kendama）最早可追溯至16至19世紀的法國，當時稱為「Bilboquet」，是一種將球體與木棒結合的遊戲，深受法國貴族喜愛[1][2][3]。
- 初期的劍玉以獸骨製成，後來逐漸演變成杯狀，最終發展出尖端與底部皿的結構，球體也增加了洞口[1][3][4]。
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/iFiiXkonsXY?si=pN_5UVjx0ARa_6Sk" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>
## 傳入日本

- 約在江戶時代（18世紀），劍玉由留學生帶入日本長崎[1][3][5]。
- 傳入初期，名稱多變，如「拳玉」、「七玉拳」等[1][5]。
- 劍玉不僅作為玩具，也曾用於占卜或飲酒遊戲[6]。

## 現代劍玉的誕生

- 大正時代（約1919年），日本廣島的江草濱次改良了劍玉結構，設計出三個皿與一個尖端，並命名為「日月球」，象徵太陽與月亮的結合[3][5][6]。
- 1919年，「日月球」獲得專利，並開始量產，劍玉逐漸成為日本全國流行的玩具[1][6]。

## 規則與競技化

- 1975年，日本劍玉協會成立，統一名稱為「けん玉」（Kendama），並制定了劍玉的標準規格與基本技巧，推動劍玉邁向競技與教育領域[1][2][3]。
- 劍玉的級位、段位制度和基本十招也在此時確立[2][3]。

## 劍玉在台灣

- 2009年，台灣成立了全國性的「中華劍球劍玉運動協會」，推廣劍玉文化[1]。

## 劍玉的現代發展

- 劍玉已成為全球知名的技巧運動與娛樂玩具，不僅在日本，歐美等地也有眾多玩家與比賽[2][3][5]。

title: 雜耍球
content:
# The History of Juggling Balls

## Ancient Origins

- **The earliest records of juggling** appear in Ancient Egypt, around 1994–1781 BCE. Tomb paintings in Beni Hasan depict female dancers and acrobats tossing balls, showing that the history of juggling balls spans over 4,000 years[1][2][3].
- **Ancient China** also documents juggling. For example, during the Western Han Dynasty, the warrior Xiong Yiliao was said to have juggled nine balls on the battlefield, intimidating enemy troops[4].
- **Ancient Greece, Rome, India, and Ireland** also have early records of juggling. For instance, the Roman juggler Tagatus Ursus was said to perform with glass balls in the 1st century CE[5][6].

## Middle Ages and Renaissance

- With the decline of the Roman Empire, juggling in Europe was often seen as a lowly or even magical act, relegated to marketplaces, streets, and taverns[4].
- By the late Middle Ages, juggling gradually regained its reputation, becoming part of court entertainment and integrating with music, poetry, and storytelling[2].

## Modern Development of Juggling Balls

### 18th–19th Centuries

- **1768:** Philip Astley founded the first modern circus in England, making juggling an important part of circus performances[1][2].
- **19th century:** Asian juggling troupes (from India and Japan) introduced new techniques to Europe, promoting the diverse development of juggling arts[7].

### Evolution of Materials and Props

- Early juggling balls were made from stone, wood, leather, metal, clay, and paper. String balls were used in China and Japan, while leather balls were common in Europe[5][8].
- **Late 19th century:** With the invention of rubber and plastic, juggling balls began to be mass-produced, including bounce balls and inflatable balls, making juggling techniques more diverse[5][4].
- **Modern juggling balls** are mostly made from plastic, rubber, or synthetic materials and come in various sizes and weights to suit different performance needs[9].

### 20th Century to Present

- **Early 20th century:** Juggling became part of vaudeville performances, leading to the rise of many professional jugglers and innovative techniques[1][2].
- **1947:** The International Jugglers’ Association was founded, promoting the global development of juggling[1].
- Today, juggling balls are not only tools for professional performers but also a popular recreational activity among enthusiasts worldwide[2][4].

## Cultural Diversity

- **Indigenous peoples of the Americas**, **Pacific Islanders**, and the **Aztec civilization** also have traditional forms of juggling balls, sometimes incorporating juggling into religious rituals[2][10].
- **Japan’s Otedama** is a beanbag juggling game that originated from China and was introduced to Japan around 710 CE[8].

The history of juggling balls spans thousands of years, from ancient Egyptian murals to modern circuses and street performances. Juggling balls not only showcase human dexterity and creativity but also reflect the exchange and fusion of different eras and cultures[5][1][2].

# 雜耍球的歷史

## 古代起源

- **最早的雜耍記錄**出現在古埃及，約公元前1994年至1781年。埃及Beni Hasan墓壁畫描繪了女性舞者和雜技演員拋接球的場景，這些圖像顯示雜耍球的歷史已有超過4000年[1][2][3]。
- **中國古代**也有雜耍的記載，例如西漢時期的勇士熊宜僚據說在戰場上拋接九顆球，嚇退敵軍[4]。
- **希臘、羅馬、印度和愛爾蘭**等地也有古老的雜耍記錄。例如，羅馬雜耍家Tagatus Ursus據說在公元1世紀使用玻璃球表演[5][6]。

## 中世紀與文藝復興

- 隨著羅馬帝國的衰落，雜耍在歐洲一度被視為低賤甚至與巫術相關的表演，只能在市集、街頭和酒館中進行[4]。
- 到了中世紀晚期，雜耍逐漸恢復名聲，成為宮廷娛樂的一部分，並與音樂、詩歌和故事講述結合[2]。

## 現代雜耍球的發展

### 18-19世紀

- **1768年**，英國的Philip Astley創辦了第一個現代馬戲團，雜耍成為馬戲團表演的重要部分[1][2]。
- **19世紀**，亞洲的雜耍團體（如印度、日本）將新技術帶入歐洲，推動了雜耍藝術的多元發展[7]。

### 材料與道具的演進

- 早期的雜耍球材料包括石頭、木頭、皮革、金屬、黏土和紙張。中國和日本曾使用線球，歐洲則常用皮革球[5][8]。
- **19世紀末**，隨著橡膠和塑膠的發明，雜耍球開始大量生產，並出現了彈跳球與充氣球，讓雜耍技巧更加多元[5][4]。
- **現代**雜耍球多以塑膠、橡膠或合成材料製成，並有各種尺寸與重量，適合不同表演需求[9]。

### 20世紀至今

- **20世紀初**，雜耍與音樂廳（Vaudeville）表演結合，催生了許多專業雜耍家與創新技巧[1][2]。
- **1947年**，國際雜耍家協會成立，推動全球雜耍運動的發展[1]。
- 今日，雜耍球不僅是專業表演者的道具，也是全球各地愛好者的熱門休閒活動[2][4]。

## 文化多樣性

- **美洲原住民**、**太平洋島嶼**、**阿茲特克文明**等地區也有雜耍球的傳統，部分文化甚至將雜耍結合宗教儀式[2][10]。
- **日本的御手玉（Otedama）**是源自中國的豆袋雜耍遊戲，約於公元710年傳入日本[8]。

雜耍球的歷史橫跨數千年，從古埃及壁畫到現代馬戲團與街頭藝術，雜耍球不僅展現人類的靈巧與創意，也反映了不同時代與文化的交流與融合[5][1][2]。

title: 雜耍球
content:
# The History of Juggling Balls

## Ancient Origins

- **The earliest records of juggling** appear in Ancient Egypt, around 1994–1781 BCE. Tomb paintings in Beni Hasan depict female dancers and acrobats tossing balls, showing that the history of juggling balls spans over 4,000 years[1][2][3].
- **Ancient China** also documents juggling. For example, during the Western Han Dynasty, the warrior Xiong Yiliao was said to have juggled nine balls on the battlefield, intimidating enemy troops[4].
- **Ancient Greece, Rome, India, and Ireland** also have early records of juggling. For instance, the Roman juggler Tagatus Ursus was said to perform with glass balls in the 1st century CE[5][6].

## Middle Ages and Renaissance

- With the decline of the Roman Empire, juggling in Europe was often seen as a lowly or even magical act, relegated to marketplaces, streets, and taverns[4].
- By the late Middle Ages, juggling gradually regained its reputation, becoming part of court entertainment and integrating with music, poetry, and storytelling[2].

## Modern Development of Juggling Balls

### 18th–19th Centuries

- **1768:** Philip Astley founded the first modern circus in England, making juggling an important part of circus performances[1][2].
- **19th century:** Asian juggling troupes (from India and Japan) introduced new techniques to Europe, promoting the diverse development of juggling arts[7].

### Evolution of Materials and Props

- Early juggling balls were made from stone, wood, leather, metal, clay, and paper. String balls were used in China and Japan, while leather balls were common in Europe[5][8].
- **Late 19th century:** With the invention of rubber and plastic, juggling balls began to be mass-produced, including bounce balls and inflatable balls, making juggling techniques more diverse[5][4].
- **Modern juggling balls** are mostly made from plastic, rubber, or synthetic materials and come in various sizes and weights to suit different performance needs[9].

### 20th Century to Present

- **Early 20th century:** Juggling became part of vaudeville performances, leading to the rise of many professional jugglers and innovative techniques[1][2].
- **1947:** The International Jugglers’ Association was founded, promoting the global development of juggling[1].
- Today, juggling balls are not only tools for professional performers but also a popular recreational activity among enthusiasts worldwide[2][4].

## Cultural Diversity

- **Indigenous peoples of the Americas**, **Pacific Islanders**, and the **Aztec civilization** also have traditional forms of juggling balls, sometimes incorporating juggling into religious rituals[2][10].
- **Japan’s Otedama** is a beanbag juggling game that originated from China and was introduced to Japan around 710 CE[8].

The history of juggling balls spans thousands of years, from ancient Egyptian murals to modern circuses and street performances. Juggling balls not only showcase human dexterity and creativity but also reflect the exchange and fusion of different eras and cultures[5][1][2].

# 雜耍球的歷史

## 古代起源

- **最早的雜耍記錄**出現在古埃及，約公元前1994年至1781年。埃及Beni Hasan墓壁畫描繪了女性舞者和雜技演員拋接球的場景，這些圖像顯示雜耍球的歷史已有超過4000年[1][2][3]。
- **中國古代**也有雜耍的記載，例如西漢時期的勇士熊宜僚據說在戰場上拋接九顆球，嚇退敵軍[4]。
- **希臘、羅馬、印度和愛爾蘭**等地也有古老的雜耍記錄。例如，羅馬雜耍家Tagatus Ursus據說在公元1世紀使用玻璃球表演[5][6]。

## 中世紀與文藝復興

- 隨著羅馬帝國的衰落，雜耍在歐洲一度被視為低賤甚至與巫術相關的表演，只能在市集、街頭和酒館中進行[4]。
- 到了中世紀晚期，雜耍逐漸恢復名聲，成為宮廷娛樂的一部分，並與音樂、詩歌和故事講述結合[2]。

## 現代雜耍球的發展

### 18-19世紀

- **1768年**，英國的Philip Astley創辦了第一個現代馬戲團，雜耍成為馬戲團表演的重要部分[1][2]。
- **19世紀**，亞洲的雜耍團體（如印度、日本）將新技術帶入歐洲，推動了雜耍藝術的多元發展[7]。

### 材料與道具的演進

- 早期的雜耍球材料包括石頭、木頭、皮革、金屬、黏土和紙張。中國和日本曾使用線球，歐洲則常用皮革球[5][8]。
- **19世紀末**，隨著橡膠和塑膠的發明，雜耍球開始大量生產，並出現了彈跳球與充氣球，讓雜耍技巧更加多元[5][4]。
- **現代**雜耍球多以塑膠、橡膠或合成材料製成，並有各種尺寸與重量，適合不同表演需求[9]。

### 20世紀至今

- **20世紀初**，雜耍與音樂廳（Vaudeville）表演結合，催生了許多專業雜耍家與創新技巧[1][2]。
- **1947年**，國際雜耍家協會成立，推動全球雜耍運動的發展[1]。
- 今日，雜耍球不僅是專業表演者的道具，也是全球各地愛好者的熱門休閒活動[2][4]。

## 文化多樣性

- **美洲原住民**、**太平洋島嶼**、**阿茲特克文明**等地區也有雜耍球的傳統，部分文化甚至將雜耍結合宗教儀式[2][10]。
- **日本的御手玉（Otedama）**是源自中國的豆袋雜耍遊戲，約於公元710年傳入日本[8]。

雜耍球的歷史橫跨數千年，從古埃及壁畫到現代馬戲團與街頭藝術，雜耍球不僅展現人類的靈巧與創意，也反映了不同時代與文化的交流與融合[5][1][2]。
